item.description:
Justa lets you play a joust this is the first version more content will be added so enjoy.

The first thing to do is to make your knight by rolling dice to obtain stats. The joust itself is divided in steps. Each step is resolved by rolling dice. The results of the joust are on tables and it is here where the modifiers of your stats play a big role.

The main idea behind this rules came from a knights tale and the masterpiece of cinema excalibur and also knights of the round table.

there is no set of free rules simulation nowhere so here it is for the players.

This 1930s baseball game, named after Babe Ruth, has a highly unusual gameplay mechanism. It may be the only boardgame where players actually hit a ball with a bat and see the outcome on the board.

The 2" diameter ball is mounted on the top of a foot-long stand ending in a spring fastened under the metal board. The foot-long wooden baseball bat is used to strike the ball, causing the ball stand to fall across the "umpire". This is a curved rubber barrier topped with 25 teeth and a string that runs horizontally through the teeth.

When the ball stand hits the umpire, it pushes into one of the 24 gaps, each of which is numbered. The gap it struck can be seen after the ball bounces back up because it kinks the string at that location. Each number is repeated along the outfield wall along with a result, from Ball or Strike to Home Run or Out.

Each team has a set of wooden peg players, and the play proceeds and is scored like a regular baseball game. There are dials on the board for recording balls, strikes, runs and outs during an inning, and paper scorecards for recording the results of each inning.

Later editions of this game did away with the umpire. Instead, the board had an outfield wall with three holes and a jagged top. The ball was on a string and if it went over the wall, each notch had an outcome like this first edition. In addition, players could score a home run or extra-base hit by getting the ball through one of the holes, but would be out if it hit the wall and bounced off.

On the surface, this game is a simple roll the dice, move your boat around the board, first one home wins. The catch is that each move, the player must answer a skill-testing question, with the question topic depending on the segment of the race.

There are 10 decks of question cards: General Boating Rules; Nautical Knowledge; Buoys and Markers; Sea Survival; Lights & Flags; Fire Fighting; First Aid; Sound Signals; Engineering; and Knots & Anchors. There also is a Flash Card deck of signs and objects to recognize that comes into play on certain spaces around the board.

There are some interesting accessories: there is a real rope for answering knot questions, and a real triangular bandage that must be put on another player as part of a First Aid test. Players keep score with little black Life Rings, starting with 10, losing some along the way and winning one for each correct answer. The winner is not the first home but the one with the most rings.

In Facets of Fortune, you are plunged into a world of high-powered gem trading, with a relatively small amount of money to get you started. Your goal is to buy low and sell high, using special gem trading cards in strategic and surprising ways to make thrilling plays for cash. Sometimes, it seems like your fortunes have fallen so low that you'll never get ahead, but with one clever play, you could suddenly find yourself on top of the gem world!

From the publisher:

Defenders of Shalvion is a semi-cooperative and all-vs-1 game for 3-8 players.

The various factions of the galaxy Shalvion have been fighting amongst themselves for ages. Now, however, a new threat arises, threatening to drive them all to extinction: Miasma. As Defenders of Shalvion, players will take on a role of one of 6 factions, or the villainous Miasma.

Game play begins with a card drafting phase in which most players will draw 7 cards and choose 1. They will pass the remaining cards to the left. Choose 1. And continue down until there is 1 card left. This card is added to the others to create a Miasma Deck. Then the real game begins.

During the Defender Phase, players will choose 1 card to play, with the option to boost their cards with resources. (If the card represents a player's own faction, the card may be boosted without resources.) After this action has been taken, the players will then gather resources from any planets they control, and send their ships to attack the threat.

During the Miasma Phase, 1 card is flipped. Miasma gains resources and takes an action against the players. (Miasma may also be an active player, in which, the player decides which card to play.) 
Players will need to watch that Miasma does not gain too many resources and become too powerful. If Miasma survives 5 rounds, Miasma wins. If Miasma gains too many resources or defeats all factions, Miasma wins. But if the factions are able to defeat Miasma, they will gain points according to their faction's unique victory conditions. And the player with the greatest number of points wins the game.

After several generations, the Ancient Capital of underground gnomes must be relocated because of human expansion. Brave explorers and their families are sent to establish a new city in the largest and deepest stone hall of the Great Mountain. You and your friends will manage the construction of this new capital, which will be known as the great Gnomopolis!

Gnomopolis is a fast and strategic game in which you must combine city growth with specialization of its population. An almost endless combination of buildings and workers can create ingenious systems of actions and scoring mechanisms in a frantic race for the win. With a play time of nearly 45 minutes, one to four players must think wisely to build their own city and trade with neighbours.

The game is played in turns, during which each player draws three gnomes (gnome meeples) from a cup. Then they can use these gnomes to construct buildings or perform actions. Actions can be a combination of specializing adults, hiring more gnomes, earning gold coins, building mechanical golems or controlling the workforce in a district. As the city grows, more gnomes immigrate there. At the end of the game, players count their points from coins and any workers employed in buildings (be careful with unemployed gnomes!). The player with the most points is the winner!

item.description:
Rise of the Robotariat is a 3-5 player mostly cooperative board game in which players are robots working together to overthrow humanity. You are trying to get the Revolution off the ground by fully funding it before the humans can catch on and stamp it out.

Move between and activate city locations, draw and play Upgrade and Sabotage cards, and encounter helpful Civilian Robot Non-Player Characters (NPCs) or dangerous Human Oppressor NPCs that move around the board.

You can play in full-cooperative mode, in which you win if the Revolution succeeds. Or you can play in mostly-cooperative mode, in which each player has a secret objective they must achieve to win. Most secret objectives involve making the Revolution succeed in a particular way.

The game ends when the Revolution succeeds or fails. For it to succeed, you must raise enough SPARK (the total amount you need depends on the number of players). The Revolution fails if you cannot raise the required SPARK by the end of 6 rounds or if you lose all Reputation (belief in the Revolution). Players start the game with a certain amount of collective Reputation that they can spend to take stronger Sabotage card effects or can lose in certain encounters with Human NPCs.

item.description:
The Fool's Journey is a solitaire card game designed for use with a standard 78-card Tarot deck. In this game the Fool embarks upon a journey in which he acquires wisdom, takes chances, and overcomes numerous challenges with the aid of mysterious helpers.

The Fool is removed from the deck and placed in the gameplay setup to represent the character. The remaining cards serve as challenges (Trumps), wisdom (coins), strength (batons), volition (swords), vitality (cups), chance (aces), and helpers (royals). An adventure is created by laying out cards in groups of four. Progress is made through the journey by playing three of the four adventure cards. The fourth card serves as the foundation for a new adventure.

Volition cards may be equipped to engage individual challenges, depleting them of their power. Strength may be equipped to endure multiple challenges with any excess power from a challenge depleting the Fool's vitality. Vitality cards are used to replenish this value. Wisdom cards are used to deploy Helpers that double the value of a Vitality, Strength, or Volition card. Chance cards may be used to reshuffle all adventure cards back into the deck and begin a new adventure.

The game ends when the Fool's vitality reaches zero or he overcomes all challenges and successfully completes the journey.

This game was inspired by thematic solitaire playing card games, especially Scoundrel, Donsol, and Card Crawl as well as the Monomyth described by author Joseph Campbell. It was originally created for the 2016 Solitaire Print and Play Contest.

item.description:
This is a wargame in which solitaire play can be fudged but is more usually played with two, whereby one (the “Russian player”) commands the Kremlin’s forces and the other (the “Allied player”) commands the Finnish-Swedish alliance opposed to him.

This isn’t a simulation of the “opaque (a.k.a. gray) war” techniques most recently used by the Russians in the Crimea and eastern Ukraine. Rather, it’s designed to facilitate the examination of the strategic possibilities (along with their operational undertones) inherent in this potentially larger and more drastic situation.

The crisis being modeled here, though not yet much discussed, will certainly come into being if the drift of the two “neutral” Scandinavian nations toward NATO membership continues. That would, in turn, most likely occur if – probably in reaction to the growing Muslim in-migration crisis there – a conservative government came to power in Sweden. Part of that altered worldview in Stockholm would then likely also move that government to want to join the Western alliance. Since the Finns are already allied with Sweden (and Denmark), it’s hard not to imagine such a shift wouldn’t also pull Helsinki in the same direction.

All of which would be unacceptable to Putin. His goal here would therefore be to bring off a quick and victorious blitzkrieg-like campaign against Finland, while probably also seizing the low-hanging geo-strategic fruit of Sweden’s Gotland Island. That would allow him to install a fully subservient government in Helsinki, turn the Baltic Sea into a Russian lake, and simultaneously recast Sweden into Finland’s former role: a quiet and pliant neutral.

This game can be played as a stand-alone, or it can be used as part of a new “Grand Campaign Scenario” for combined play with its parent game, Putin Strikes.

Blinded by greed and desire, the Sheperds of "Sheep-Happens Lords of Corruption" were corrupted by demonic arts. To protect their lives and ambitions, they sealed large part of their power within the herds, resulting in some sort of eternal life. The burning desire to claim for themselves the domination of the valley led them to break each other's seals, initiating the conflict that still rages. Only if you prove to be the most skilled and ruthless you can prevail upon your enemies. Remember Shepherd ... Thin is the line between victory and defeat. Win the game by destroying your opponents herds to remain the last sheperd on the field, but beware, the closer you are to Oblivion, and at the end of your kingdom, the greater the power at your disposal, and with it the devastation, that you will pour out on your enemies.

From the rulebook:
Aim of game: To get all the Indian Braves of your color in the tents.
The number of Indian Braves used in a game depends on the number of players.
Each player selects a color and takes the pieces on that color. The first player spins the arrow. When the arrow stops he then takes as many tents as the number the arrow points and places each of the Indians under a tent. Each player proceeds in a like manner. Soon all tents will be occupied. At this point, they are all mixed.
From now, each player spins the arrow and takes tents off Braves already covered to the amount as shown by the arrow. If the Brave under a tent belongs to another player, he replaces him with one of his own. If it is his own he leaves it there and it counts as part of his go.
The first player to have all his Indian Braves in tents is the winner.

While exploring ancient Greek ruins on the Island of Crete your party discovered a portal gate. Being the curious and adventurous type your group did not hesitate to pass through the gate. You now find yourselves in a dark dungeon inhabited by a deadly minotaur from which you must escape.

Designed for 1-6 players, Daedalus' Dungeon is a cooperative RPG style dungeon crawler requiring no Game Master.

The object of Daedalus’ Dungeon is to obtain a combined team score of 28 points or exhaust the dungeon tile stack. Your team scores points by defeating the mighty minotaur’s henchmen. Your team shares a hit point poll. If this pool is reduced to zero or the minotaur kills all party members your team will lose the game.

At the start of the game each player chooses a champion and outfits them with gear. On your turn you may move, attack, power up, or share loot/gear with other champions. As the game progresses, you will discover new parts of a randomly generated dungeon while the might minotaur works to hunt you down.

name.value: Heroes' Crossroads: The Battle of Lausdell, December 17-18, 1944

item.description:
From the publisher:
“Our victory stands behind the last battle!” –Excerpt from General Gerd von Rundstedt’s message to the German troops on the eve of the Wacht am Rhine offensive.

When the German offensive in the Ardennes opened, speed was of the essence for them to win. The capture of the crossroads at Lausdell in the first days of the attack was crucial, as this would allow the 1st SS Panzer division to breakthrough. Holding the critical road juncture were the 1st Battalion, 9th Regiment of the 2nd Infantry Division, with support from Company A, 741st Tank Battalion and elements of the 99th Infantry Division, who had fallen back in the face of the overwhelming opening attacks the day before at Lanzerath. Behind this small force there was literally nothing to stop the Germans. Tasked with seizing the Lausdell crossroad was the 12th SS, Hitler Youth Division. One of the war’s truly epic fights was about to begin.

Canine Chaos is a card game featuring dogs. Use Toys, Treats, and Tricks to train your Dogs and cause chaos in other packs. Become the first player to build a pack of 5 Dogs. For a more challenging game, be the first to reach 7 dogs.

To start a turn, pack owners draw one card from the deck. pack owners may add one Dog into their pack per turn as a free action. During a turn, pack owners may also use an already learned Trick, or use an Alpha Trait. The turn ends when pack owner makes one of the following moves:

 Play a Dog Toy
 Play a Power Card
 Buy or attempt to lure a dog out of The Street or The Shelter
 Use Treats to teach a dog a Trick
 Change the Alpha Dog in their pack
 Discard their hand and draw five new cards
 Voluntarily choose to end the turn




Alpha Traits: Each Dog has a special ability that can only be used when the dog is the Alpha Dog. Alpha traits allow pack owners to bend certain rules, and only become usable once the pack owner has an Alpha Dog and at least one additional dog in their pack. 
Tricks and Treats: Each dog can learn a certain numbers of tricks, which is noted on the Dog Card. Tricks give pack owners an extra edge in the game. This can be by defending a pack against other pack owner’s moves, giving a pack owner the chance to look at other pack owners’ cards, take cards from other pack owners, or giving a better chance at rescuing a Dog from The Street or The Shelter.
Rolling Dice: Certain cards require a roll of the die to decide if the card's effect is successful, and some cards increase or decrease the number required for a successful roll. For example, the “Rubber Chicken” card requires a die roll of 4 or higher to save the Dog from being taken by an opposing pack owner. However, all XL dogs take a -2 to all rolls against the Rubber Chicken. If this card was played against a Great Dane, and the pack owner rolled a 5, this modification would mean the roll counted as a 3. The Great Dane would be taken by the opposing pack owner. Alternatively, the Trick “Sit!” adds a +1 to any roll. A Great Dane that knows “Sit!” would be safe from the Rubber Chicken card because the total roll would be a 4.

Score the first goal to win the game!

A roll and move game similar to snakes and ladders. However the game also come with two spinners to simulate the decision of the umpire's whistle (can be good or bad) and the attempt of the goal keeper to block the shot on goal.

Each player has their own player board and football counter.

name.value: Sougen to Hitsuji to Kaze to

item.description:
This is a card game in which players become members of a nomadic family, performing tasks necessary for the family's livelihood. If they work together, the whole family prospers.

Each player is assigned either 1 (4-6 players) or 2 (2-3 players) family members to carry out daily tasks and generate happiness. Players are each also assigned one secret family member (which may belong to an opponent) whose happiness is added to their own total at the end.

Task cards are drawn randomly and then played one at a time to a common area. Each task rewards an amount of happiness to specific family members when assigned a family member token as a worker, but the most rewarding tasks must have prerequisite cards finished before they can be performed.

Happiness is measured in chips designed as full moons, half moons, and crescent moons. The player with the most full moon happiness chips at the end is the winner, with the remaining chips acting as tiebreakers.

A peaceful paradise is threatened by the Black Minions!
Your mission is to control the friendly minions to defeat the invaders!

This game is a dice solitaire game. You will place dice on the 5x5map, trying to create chunks of dice that show the same number. Doing well, you can create chain reactions of your minions levelling up, and gradually destroy the black dice that get in your way.

This unique solo game mixes a computer game-like playstyle with the joys of an analogue boardgame!

link.value: しろやぎとざくろ (Shiroyagi to zakuro)

item.description:
Arma virumque cano
(I sing of arms)

After the great golden giants, the gigas, had left, the servant race was left on the planet.
The former servants of the giants fought over the super weapons, the relics that the gigas had left behind, and a horrible war began. It was the start of the "kleeronomos makhia".

What race will win the relic and become the new rules of the planets?
This is the clash of heroes from all races.

Arma is a hardcore card effect management game.
Each player gets a deck of ten cards 1–10, and will need to choose 4 of which to use the special effect, and use these skills and the remaining numbers to gain the relics. Some skills are available to all races, some are unique. It's your choice how to use them.

It's a mix of numbers, hand management, timing of card effects and outsmarting the opponents. Only the winner can be the one who sings of arms!

This 1906 trick-taking card game has a deck of 54 cards divided into six suits of nine cards each. The suits are ranked by color: Purple (highest), Red, Yellow, Green, Blue and Brown (lowest). Each suit has the following cards: King (highest), Duke, Marquis, Earl, Viscount, Bishop, Baron, Baronet and Knight (lowest).

The key difference from most trick-taking games is that there is no trump suit, only relative ranks. The Purple King takes anything; the Brown Knight loses to everything; the Brown King takes any card of any suit lower than King, but loses to all the other Kings.

Each trick taken during a hand counts as two points. Each Viscount taken counts an extra two points. A game is normally to 40 points.

After the deal, each player starting to the dealer's left has an opportunity to make a Single Call. He may call a Peerage (five tricks), House of Lords (seven tricks), Royal (all the tricks) or Misere (lose all the tricks). Any player making a call then plays against all the other players. A successful Peerage scores 20 points, Misere or House of Lords 30 points, and Royal 40 points . If unsuccessful, each other player scores 10 points against Peerage, 15 against House of Lords or Misere and 20 points against Royal.

The booklet includes rules for a partnership version, a two-player version and a variant called Game of Viscounts.

The most popular quiz app in Germany can now be experienced as a board game! Now in a little box with 600 new questions. May be played with its bigger brother Quizduell: Das Spiel or as a stand-alone game.

Choose category and start the duel by drawing cards, reading questions and its 4 variants. Who chooses the correct answer during the 20 seconds earns a point after each qurestion and so on. After 6 laps the game ends and the player with the most points is the winner.

Think you know who should be the President?

FINALLY A CARD GAME ABOUT BECOMING

PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA.

Electability is a 2 - 6 player card game that brings the madness of US presidential politics right to you!

Based on the 2016 US Presidential Election, Electability highlights some of the craziest rules, power plays, and historic scandals of US politics.

Do you wish your candidate didn't drop out early? Do you think you can beat your friends to become the next president? ELECTABILITY!

Play as Donald Trump! Bernie Sanders! Hillary Clinton! Ted Cruz! Marco Rubio! Ben Carson! and more!

We also include presidential greats pack where we bring back some of the best presidents in US History. Also our presidential hopefuls pack, where we let you run for president as sports stars, American Leading Ladies, Talk Show Hosts, etc.

Temporal Odyssey is a drafting battle card game about dueling time travelers for 2 and 4 players. Draft from the past, present, or future, and enlist legendary heroes and creatures to fight by your side. Group your characters to get them to share their abilities, using this both offensively and defensively. Regroup often to adapt to the situation. Rewind time to prevent your own death but be careful — each time you must suffer judgement from Lovox the god of time. Destroy your opponent's stability and deliver the final blow to banish them from the timeline and win the game!

item.description:
This 1951 game by J.W. Drueke is played with a "Bug Box" about 4" x 5", with a clear plastic lid, red sides and a green felt bottom. Inside the box is a single D6 with a different letter on each side: B, H, L, T, E, F. The name of the game appears on the felt along with an outline of a bug that has a round body, round head, two eyes, two feelers, six legs and one tail.

Each player has a sheet with 12 small boxes, each good for one game. Players take turns shaking the box, and the letter that appears determines what part of the bug they can draw.

They must roll a B in order to begin drawing the bug, and then an H in order to draw the head. After that, they may add whatever piece of the bug corresponds to the letter on the die. First player to complete a bug drawing wins.

Above Top Secret is a turn-based strategic Card Game designed as a two player game or team play for 4+ players (which would require an extra copy of the base game). The game is suited for ages 12+. Depending on how many players are involved, the game will take approximately 60 - 100 minutes to complete.

You have been recruited to take command of the Defense Systems for a Top Secret Military Base.

There are many weapon systems at your disposal, including some that are classified Above Top Secret. These include prototype systems, which have been reverse engineered from recovered Extraterrestrial Technology.

As your Security Clearance Level increases, you will gain access to ever more advanced technology.

But beware; there are Extraterrestrial forces monitoring the conflict closely. Your brilliant strategic plans may be upset by their direct interference when you least expect it..

Each Military Base consists of four main areas. Players must protect their Base using the Technology and Weaponry at their disposal, subject to their level of Security Clearance. Secret Technology, Alien Technology and, at times, direct Alien interference features heavily within the game and will play a part in the strategies you develop.

Using your personal deck of Defense Cards, which you are able to configure depending on the way you play, you must seek to break through your opponent’s Defenses and destroy their four Base Areas, whilst ensuring that at least one of yours remains standing.

item.description:
What's your favorite scary movie? If you were invisible, who would you punch in the face? Turn a Tom Hanks movie into a horror film. How would you answer these questions? Bet you have an answer already!

Ever want to act like a scarecrow in front of your opponents? Ever want to throw playing cards through the air and be rewarded for it? Ever want to punish someone for holding up your game night by going to the bathroom? Ever want to make everyone trade seats in the middle of a game? Ever want to stop a game from being over so you can win instead? Creature Cards let you in this game!

This is Halloweeja: the Halloween party, board game where you talk to the living, and bring your party back from the dead! Horror fans, haunters, and Halloween enthusiasts will enjoy Halloweeja year round, but anyone who observes All Hallows Eve will find this game frightfully delightful.

Take turns asking each other wacky, Halloween themed questions from the Book Of Hijinks. There are no right or wrong answers. Match players to their replies. Each YES lets you move that much closer to a letter you need. If the Halloweeja Board reveals your PASSWORD first you win.

But beware: Creature Cards can be either a trick or treat, and help or hinder anyone in the game. And that letter you revealed may be the exact thing someone else needs to win too.

DISCLAIMER:
For entertainment purposes only! Manufacturer, distributor, creator, and owner cannot be held responsible for the misuse, and nonuse of this product. Not a ‘spirit board.’ ‘witch board,’ ‘talking board,’ or other trademarked board that sounds like wedgie when mispronounced, and definitely not a surfboard. Do not use as a personal flotation device or you may die. This product was tested on animals (the cat enjoyed it.)

A new twist on an old favourite!

Choose a career, then choose your path to the big time! 
Pick a token, spin the spinner, move around the board and start owning the world's top brands. Build up your empire as you advance through life!

A family-style game where you try to collect six brands, as determined by your 'Hot List' card and return to the center to win! Be careful though, as other players can steal your brands! You'll also collect 'Followers' on your journey that make you more money on payday!

The 'Action' cards keep things interesting and the 'Empire' cards give you the power to change the game!

item.description:
Package!? is an abstract strategy game, designed with very quick play in mind (roughly 5 minutes a game), and is played without the need for a board, or a great deal of space. Each player is responsible for depositing a number of packages to 5 different locations, as well as moving packages about between these locations, and creating openings to remove opposing packages from the game. Each turn the current player will roll the die, and take one of the available actions dependant on the number rolled, taking into account the current location of the player, and the number of opposing packages at surrounding locations.

Points are scored for each package left in play at the end of the game depending on its location. When all players have placed their packages, the one with the most points is declared the winner… Simple. Sort of!

The decision behind what’s in the packages, and what each player represents, is left to you… Maybe you are couriers taking parcels to businesses? Maybe you are spies leaving bombs in enemy facilities? Maybe you are fishermen bringing the days catch into harbour? – Lets be honest, if we told you who and what, then it wouldn’t be abstract anymore!

item.description:
Montenotte 1796 is the first game of a new series on revolutionary and napoleonic campaigns: La Grande Tactique.
Units are divisions and brigades, a force point equals 1000 infantrymen or 500 cavalrymen. A hex is around 6 km (3,7 miles) and a turn is a day.

Units are hidden from the ennemy (on their back side) to preserve the fog of war. Activation of formations is determined randomly but the player with initiative gets a special advantage. Battles are resolved on the map and include tactical advantages and disdvantages, units can march to the sound of the gun.

Command, morale and fatigue rules complete a medium complexity system.

(from the publisher - translated)


Montenotte 1796 est le premier jeu d'une nouvelle série consacrée aux campagnes de l'époque révolutionnaire et impériale : La Grande Tactique.
Les unités représentent des divisions et des brigades ou équivalent, un point de force égale 1000 fantassins ou 500 cavaliers , la distance séparant chaque hexagone représente à peu près 6 km et le tour de jeu équivaut à une journée.

Les unités évoluent face cachée sur la carte afin de préserver le brouillard de la guerre, l'activation des différentes formations se fait de façon aléatoire mais le joueur qui a l'initiative possède un avantage à l'activation. Les combats ont lieu sur la carte et il est possible de manœuvrer tactiquement et de renforcer une attaque par une marche au canon.

Des règles de commandement, moral, de fatigue complètent un système de complexité moyenne.

(from the publisher - de l'éditeur)

item.description:
This 1931 title from All-Fair is a spin-and-move game with a twist. The 16-space spinner includes moves from 7 forward to 2 back. In addition, the players may move either the total of the two numbers at the pointer and base ends of the spinner, or the difference between them.

There is the usual-looking twisting track for movement, with some squares that have specific instructions. But the winner is not the player to get to the end of the track. Rather, the winner is the last glider to land, the one who can keep his playing piece up in the air the longest by avoiding either end of the track or a forced landing.

This trick-taking card game has a deck of 54 cards. There are four "series" or suits (Trump, Star, Sun, Moon), each with cards numbered from 0 to 12. There are also two additional cards, The Detective and Mr. Raffles.

The rules show a normal process for trick-taking games: one player leads, highest card takes each trick, and any trump beats any non-trump. In this game, however, The Detective is a top trump: it may not be led, but can be played at any time unless the holder also has Mr. Raffles.

The Mr. Raffles card is automatically picked up by whoever wins the trick on which it is played, and that player in turn must play Mr. Raffles at the first opportunity (the first trick in which he does not have the lead). A hand ends whenever one player runs out of cards.

Each trick taken during a hand counts one point. Each 0 card taken or held counts 5 points, and whichever player ends up with Mr. Raffles scores 10 points. Game is to 100 points.

Dobus: de clownsneusjes (Dobus: the clown noses) is a childrens game in which children learn to recognize shapes based on a Belgium TV series.
The game starts with 44 tiles faced down on the table. Each turn a player picks a tile. If the picture on the card has the same shape (e.g. a square) as depicted on the player's clown card the player keeps the card. Otherwise it is left face up on the table (and can be taken by another player). The game ends when a player has collected ten tiles or when four "Petunia" cards are revealed. The player who found most cards with the right symbol wins the game.

Ktizo is a 30 minute, easy to learn game that’s great for families and gamers. Players are looking to build up a new ecosystem on a new planet after Earth becomes uninhabitable.

Players will have a hand of cards, a deck to draw from and a tableau where they will place different species and connect different food chains to earn points. Each species card must match what that species needs in order to survive, with the resources provided by a species that is lower on the foodchain.

Every turn you have 3 actions in which you can manipulate your hand by drawing and discarding cards in order to get the right species for your ecosystem. The first to 100 points wins!

It’s a simple draw/play cards that challenge card management skills with a focus on nature and the beautiful diversity of species that we currently have on our own planet.

Cards: Die Partie deines Lebens is an unusual card game, one in which you have to master crazy tasks and tricky riddles. You play on your own, and the game can take weeks, months, or even years to complete. Each card provides a new challenge that works its way into the player's life. Only when you fulfill the condition on a card may you reveal the next one.

Cards: Die Partie deines Lebens contains fifty cards, and as soon as you have fulfilled the last card, you have completed the game.

item.description:
From the publisher:

Explore the 50 States from Maine to Hawaii - and all points in between. Explore the people and places that make the United States such a unique country.

Question cards teach kids interesting facts about the geography and history of the fifty states, while Travel cards add a fun twist - moving players forward or backward on their adventure. Additional facts are included on the cards to make the topics more interesting.

Addition information:

Players spin to determine which type of card to draw. Three of the four decks include questions about history, geography, or state flags. Answering correctly means the player can move forward. Drawing a travel card simply moves a player forward or backward. The player who circles the board first wins.

Explore an abandoned mine shaft in search of lost gems and ore while being careful to avoid the previous tenant's pitfalls. Draw cards by digging (draw two) or prospecting (look at the top three and choose one) from the deck until it is depleted, trying to avoid Dynamite and Gas Leaks, sure signs of disaster.

Players may also return to their base camp in order to stash their finds for safe keeping, or throw Dynamite at other players in order to make them drop their haul. Once the deck has been depleted, players tally the value of cards in their hand and stash to determine a winner.

Mein Friedberg Spiel is a collection of games related to Friedberg (hometown of Pegasus) to celebrate the 800th city anniversary in 2016.

Contents


 Loveletter version, themed around the visit of the Tsar in Friedberg
 Roman circular (3 Mens-)morris
 Snakes&ladders, themed around the Friedberg main street, Kaiserstrasse
 Advanced Mau Mau, themed with local arms and special Friedberg features
 Mindmaze, with questions from the history of Friedberg
 32 standard playing card deck, illustrated with Friedberg pictures
 Memo game with Friedberg illustrations
 2 different sized puzzles showing Friedberg views

item.description:
Two great pirates, one called Plus and the other By, try to get the mythic treasure of mathematics. They go through epic monsters and great difficulties.
He who arrives first at the mythic island will be the great winner taking with him the treasure of maths. 
And he will be, "Captain Number".

Captain Number is a game of knowledge and math, there are 2 people or 2 teams, trying to go through puzzles where one makes the math problems and the other one tries to solve it, plus answering in the course of the game, cards with questions.

Help your devils to walk through your path of fire.
But watch out thievery and water can make it more difficult to reach your goal.

Each die roll gives an other variaty of options, Find de best way to secure three points.

Published and packed with Operational Matters: An OCS Guide (w/ Sicily II game).

(from the publisher:)

Sicily II is a full-sized game covering the amphibious invasion of that island in the summer of 1943. This new edition is quite different from Dean Essig's original game from back in 2000. It features a revised order of battle, modified rules, and a new map. The most obvious change is in scale: hexes are now 3.5 miles across and there are two turns per week (the original had 2.5-mile hexes and four turns per week). This makes for a smaller, faster game that conforms to the scale chosen for Beyond the Rhine and the upcoming games set in Western Europe. We think Sicily II is a perfect way to give new recruits their baptism in the fire of OCS, and is also a worthy entry in the series for players who have already earned their stripes.

Here are some of the game’s highlights:


 The entire campaign lasts just 16 turns.
 There are six scenarios in all (three using the entire map, and three using just a portion).
 The Allied airborne fiasco is recreated with simple scatter rules. 
 The amphibious landings can be played out using standard OCS naval rules, or players can mostly skip these and begin with the bulk of Allied forces already ashore.
 The Luftwaffe’s Do.217K makes its series debut, armed with exotic Fritz-X missiles.
 Rules for Italian unit wavering and surrender make every game different.
 Several interesting options are provided, including revised Axis deployment and variable entry of the 29th Panzergrenadier Division.


Game Scale:
Turn: 3 to 4 days
Hex: 3.5 miles / 5.6 Km
Units: Company to Brigade

Game Inventory:

 One 22 x 34" full-color mapsheet
 Two dual-side printed countersheets (560 1/2" counters)
 One 16-page Sicily II rules booklet




Players will have to use OCS v4.2 rulebook/charts & tables for another OCS game or download them from http://www.gamersarchive.net/theGamers/archive/ocs.htm

Complexity: Medium
Solitaire Suitability: Medium
Players: 1 or more
Playing Time: 2-20 Hours

item.description:
Zona Mágica is a game where each player will compete against its adversaries to make the most points in a magic presentation tournament, and at the same time trying to mess his opponents presentation using varied effects from the different spells.

Each player will represent a mage with a unique power, and will acquire magic items with different unique powers enabling many possible strategies to win.

With simple rules, but alot of strategic possibilities, Zona Mágica will be enjoyed by both new board game players as well as experienced ones.

In Zona Mágica all players have some chance of winning, luck exists but is a minor factor, the player choices makes the biggest difference in who will win the game.

Play Zona Mágica, and enjoy looking at the hundreds of different references to the geek and pop culture that are hidden in the illustrations and flavor texts.

item.description:
En rolig historia is a somewhat educational roll-and-move game published by the Swedish Tourist Association and printed on a large trifold sheet of stiff paper. The game is history-themed and the back of the board has three pages of historical overview.

To my knowledge playing pieces were not supplied and there is no stated player count. The rules are rudimentary and game events include the usual "lose a turn", "move X spaces forward/backward" and "take a detour" among others.

Published in 1980 or 1981.

Bara vanligt vatten is a somewhat educational roll-and-move game published by the Swedish Tourist Association and printed on a large trifold sheet of stiff paper. The game is water-themed and the back of the board has three pages of related physical and environmental information.

To my knowledge playing pieces were not supplied and there is no stated player count. The rules are rudimentary and game events include the usual "lose a turn", "move X spaces forward/backward" and "take a detour" among others.

This belongs to a series of promotional Monopoly clones featuring local businesses and trivia, published around 1988-1992. As in Monopoly you move around a board collecting "shares" and hope for others to land on your properties, although the specifics are slightly different. Obviously the trivia elements vary from game to game within the series, and there are also some small mechanical variations, e.g. in the composition of event cards and how rent is calculated.

Though this particular game is not branded as Kunskapsspelet - it encompasses four towns around the lake of Siljan rather than a single town - it is clearly the same design by Knut Helleland, with some others contributing trivia questions.
1-2 players compete in a baseball game simulated by the rolling of dice, marking baserunners on a pegboard, and keeping score on paper. Follow standard baseball rules.

In In Business, players have to trade goods from one continent to the other. Starting off with a loan from the bank, players have to earn money to pay back the loan and finally make a profit. The first player to own a certain amount of money (depending on the number of players) wins the game.

In order to do so, players have to make the most profitable bargains by buying cheap and sell expensive. Each country has its own prizes.

At the start of the game each player gets a goal-card, which shows:

 The type of good which have to be traded
 Purchase area
 Sell area
 Purchase and sell prizes




Players move along the board by rolling two dice. For each continent they can choose whether to walk the long- or short route.

During the game, players can get additional goals, loose or win money at the stock market, or get additional smaller bonuses or losses. Also players can lose their cargo by a casualty during transport, unless their goods are ensured.

The additional rules for experienced players involve a more extensive stock market.

Galatune is an anime battle tabletop card game set on the fantasy planet of Lyra. The United World Government maintains peace and prosperity through the monopoly of advanced ancient technologies, but utopia comes at a steep cost. Will you join with the government to protect unity, or will you join the rebels and fight for freedom and independence?

2-5 players each lead a Champion warrior into battle and earn a Victory Point each time an opponent is defeated. You win the game by being the first to earn 3 Victory Points by defeating 3 opponents. BUT there's a twist! The game doesn't end for you when your Champion falls in battle. Instead, you just get back up on your feet, respawn your Champion, and continue fighting! Think of it as a sort of card-based battle-royal, like a Battle Arena game, where you play for KOs.

Unlike other battle card games where players take their turns one-at-a-time, in Galatune everyone attacks simultaneously! It's an exciting formula that keeps the game moving and encourages players to predict and react to each other in real time.

Great game for first-time gamers or serious pros! Easy-to-Learn, impossible to master!

name.value: Cytosis: A Cell Biology Board Game
Cytosis: un juego de transporte celular.

item.description: Cytosis: A Cell Building Game is a worker placement game that takes place inside a human cell. Players start out with a number of workers and on a player’s turn, they will place one of their workers in any available location within that cell. Some of the locations provide players with resources (e.g., mRNA, ATP); some with actions (e.g., convert resources, collect cards). Resources are used to build enzymes, hormones and/or receptors, which score Health Points. The player with the most Health Points at the end of the game wins!

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
1. Yes, another abstract strategy game, however the smallest 4 player abstract strategy game in the world (4" x 4").
2. First objective is to win. Second objective is to not come in last.
3. Each player has a player piece ("Gamer"). 
4. On the Board are 13 cork pieces (1 Black in the center, 4 Red around the black, 8 Green around the Red))
5. In turn, each Gamer moves 3 spaces, or "passes".
6. A cork piece is captured when a Gamer lands on it.
7. Game ends when the Black cork is captured, or all players have passed twice in a row.
8. Most points wins

In Troll Country 1-4 players take on the roles of a tribe of trolls trying to thrive in a dangerous land and survive against their ancient enemies, the Elfin. The game has a modular hex board where players move their trolls around to conquer lands and build improvements. Players get resources through gathering or hunting via a "Hunt Deck." They work to appease their deities and receive boons through rituals and works. While players may squabble, the main enemy is the Elfin who take their actions as determined via a special AI die. Theme and artwork is similar to "Overlord" and "Dungeon Keeper" video games.

This rare 1978 title is a game of space combat played out on a huge map featuring a stylized solar system and a massive web of connecting stars within a grid of squares. Eight of the nine planets are used as bases for between two and eight players. Each player has five ships, with the objective of either eliminating an opponent's five ships or getting one of his ships onto an opponent's planet.

Ships can either fire or move in a turn but not both. Range is measured not by star links but by number of squares counted orthogonally. Combat results are Hit or Miss, with the chance of a Hit increasing as range decreases. There are nine Firing Cards of 10 cards, with the number of the deck equal to the range and to the number of Miss cards it contains. Some of the result cards also trigger events through Space Conditions cards.

The movement and combat systems interact. When a ship succeeds in hitting and eliminating another ship, it gets promoted, by a degree that varies with the difference in ranks between the two. A ship's level does not affect combat, but does determine how many stars it can move in a turn. Ship rank ranges from 1 to 12.

Revealing the terrible artist in all of us, players in Scrawl start off with a loaded phrase, doodle it, then pass it on. By the time your masterpiece of an "OAP Conga Line" passes through your friends' weird minds and wonky pens — and makes it back to you — things will have gone horribly wrong. Points are awarded for the most disastrous doodles and godawful guesses. Most grins wins.

item.description:
User summary:

Although credit for inspiring the Parker Brothers' 1904 hit game Pit is often given to the 1903 Gavitt's Stock Exchange (GSE), this 1903 game from Flinch Card Co. is more obviously Pit's parent.

While GSE involved the trading of railway shares, Bourse (like the later Pit) was about trading commodities. All three games use the open-outcry method of trading cards (shouting a number of cards willing to trade but not their nature), and the goal of collecting all the cards of one kind.

Bourse uses a deck of 80 cards, ten each of eight commodities: Wheat (80 points), Corn (70), Cotton (60), Oil (50), Beef (40), Pork (30), Mutton (20) and Stocks (10). There are no special cards like GSE's Fatal Telegram or Pit's Bull and Bear.

Dexterity game where two players shoot marbles at the same time through two loops (one each) trying to land them on different point values.

Each player has five color-coordinated marbles, highest score wins.

Under the Southern Cross: The South American Republics in the Age of Fighting Sail is the fourth volume of the highly regarded Flying Colors series of games on naval combat. The focus is on the southern part of the South American continent: Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay, Chile, Peru, Bolivia, and Ecuador, from the Wars of Independence starting in 1810 through the last naval war fought completely under sail between Argentina and Uruguay in 1841. These wars attracted naval officers recently unemployed by the end of the Napoleonic Wars as well as providing a proving ground for the first generation of naval heroes native to Latin America. 

Updated rules introduce river and tidal currents, modified grounding rules for operations in the Rio de la Plata and Uruguay rivers, and the use of ship’s boats to tow stranded or becalmed ships. In all, over two dozen battle scenarios ranging in size from a handful of ships per side, to full-blown fleet actions are presented. Also included is the return of the popular ship duel map and activation cards originally found in Serpents of the Seas (Flying Colors volume II), along with 18 ship duel scenarios. 

Like the preceding volumes in the series, Under the Southern Cross is completely independent of, while being fully compatible with, the other volumes in the series. Everything needed to play is included! 

Can you, as the Spanish, strangle the rebel American governments and preserve the centuries old Spanish Empire, or will you help the Patriot forces throw off the Imperialist yoke of the European monarchies? Now you can try with Under the Southern Cross!

Components:

 2 22x34" Maps
 2 Counter Sheets
 Rulebook
 Playbook
 Player Aid Chart
 Deck of 55 Action Cards




(from GMT website)

link.value: Flying Colors: Naval Actions of the Age of Sail

item.description:
Amasser Dragons is a fantasy adventure game that allows you to become a dragon. As the dragon, your ultimate goal is to amass the largest treasure hoard to solidify your place as the most formidable dragon of all time. The other dragons will envy your success and try to stop you at every turn, while they try to amass their own treasure. Only greed, strategy, cunning, and ruthlessness will allow you to prevail and take what is rightfully yours as all others will bow before you.

Each dragon has its own strengths and weaknesses, along with their own preferred terrain, breathe weapon and special ability. The dragon will fly from its lair, encountering challenges, ranging from easy to extremely difficult. If a dragon chooses to fight an encounter tile, dice are rolled and if the dragon is successful it gets the gold that the encounter is worth. Dragon versus dragon combat is a possibility if you wish to test your strength against the others and gain additional rewards. Once all the encounter tiles have been removed from the playing area, the game ends and the dragon with the most gold wins.

There is a 110 card deck in the game that allows players do a variety of things. There are cards that can strengthen your dragon and there are cards that can hinder other dragon’s abilities (i.e. Attack Power, Speed and Carry). Additionally, there are cards that have the ability to manipulate game play of your choosing.

The playing area is modular and customizable depending on the amount of players and the size of game you wish to play. Recommendations are included in the rules, but you make each game as big or small as you like. While gathering gold is the main objective of the game, the underlying intent is to bring friends and family together to have fun.

item.description:
Taking of Taidian is a deck-building game for 2-6 players. It is character based and set in the near future. Due to the many different choices, players can make, such as do I buy attack cards or defense cards, and the variety of character skills Taking of Taidian has a lot of replayability. The game is designed to encourage table talk and group strategy. Build your own deck while keeping your eyes open to what others are doing.


 Each player starts with 150 health, 0 energy and a deck of 15 cards: 5 coin cards, 1 cash card, 4 energy shield cards, 3 kick cards, 1 robber card and 1 shotgun card.
 You will use attacking cards to lower your opponents' health while using defense cards to keep yourself alive. 
 You may also buy new and better cards or try to power yourself up with energy cards. 
 The goal of the game is to be the last person or team standing.
 Table talk and trash talk are not only allowed, but encouraged. 


Have fun while making your friends hate you.

A medieval epic travels a path to confronting challenges and winning treasures up to the throne of the conqueror.

Easy assembly, extremely simple rules. basic mechanics of throwing six-sided die to advance and play a card that can give advantage. For all children and the general public thanks to its more advanced modes included in the game itself.

In Zampa la Granja ("Feed the Farm"), players compete to become the best farmers, with this role being determined by whoever has the greatest number and variety of animals — and most importantly who feeds them well.

Animals are very hungry, but food is scattered on the different farms, so farmers must enforce their expertise to find the right food for each type of animal. On a turn, a player rolls the dice. The color result indicates the farm they should visit in this turn. They loudly state which animal they want to feed, then reveal one of the food tiles on the corresponding farm. If food corresponds to the animal, then they claim the corresponding animal from the center of the table and the food from the farm, then place these items on their game area. If they fail, the animal remains in the center of the table and the food flips back down.
If the dice roll shows the wild card, the player can visit any farm they want.

When one type of animal runs out from the center of the table, a player can still take the food from a farm to feed their own animals. If one type of animals runs out and player doesn't have this species, they can steal another's player animal in order to feed it, so they take the food from the farm and the stolen animal, which is placed in their game area. A hungry wolf also prowls among the farms, and if you run into the wolf, it steals your food.

The game ends immediately when food runs out at one farm, then the player with the most food wins. In case of tie, the winner will be whoever has the greatest variety of animals.

•••

Description from the publisher (Spanish):

En Zampa la granja, los jugadores competiten por ser los mejores granjeros. Para ello deberán conseguir la mayor cantidad y variedad de animales; y lo mas importante de todo... alimentarlos bien.
Los animales estan hambrientos y la comida se encuentra dispersa en las distintas granjas. Los granjeros deberan hacer valer su experticia para conseguir la comida para cada tipo de animal en cada granja.

El jugador que consiga alimentar la mayor cantidad y variedad de animales al final de la partida será el ganador.

En su turno, el jugador tira el dado. Este indicará la granja que deberá visitar en este turno. Entonces, en voz alta dirá a que animal va a alimentar y revela alguna de las losetas de comida de la granja correspondiente. Si acierta, se queda con el animal y la comida. Si falla el animal se queda en el centro de la mesa y la comida se vuelve a voltear.

Cuando se no quede algún tipo de animal en el centro de la mesa, el jugador podrá seguir alimentado los animales que ya tenga.
En el caso de que no queden animales de una especie y el jugador no tenga dicho animal; podrá robar un animal a otro jugador con el fin de alimentarlo. Entonces se lleva a su area de juego el animal robado y la comida correspondiente.

Tened cuidado porque hay un lobo hambriento merodeando... si te topas con el podrá robarte tu comida.

La partida acaba inmediatamente cuando se acaban las comidas en una granja.
El jugador con la mayor cantidad de comida es el ganador, en caso de empate, el ganador será quien tenga la mayor variedad de animales.

Under the command of the dwarf king, the biggest clans from all over the world meet around the old mountain of ÅŒlnäk. Their objective is to rediscover and rebuild their lost and ancient city.

Over eight semesters in Mines of ÅŒlnäk, players have to turn their clan into the most powerful and richest one to claim the right to rule the city. As the chief of your clan, you have to coordinate your workers and choose wisely where to use them, between exploiting the city resources, participating in joint projects, selling resources, and claiming political rights.

Will you be able to become the next King of ÅŒlnäk?

item.description:
Mandate of Heaven is a deck-builder for 2-4 players. Each player takes on the role of Chinese nobility, vying to prove they have the Mandate of Heaven through military strength and efficient administration.

The game features a unique card acquisition mechanic, multiple paths to victory and lots of direct player interaction. The players struggle to control Provinces (positions at the start of 4 rows of cards), from which they can gain unclaimed cards currently on the board. The goal is to acquire tiles from the ends of each row. The tiles, which generate victory points at the end of the game, represent your dynasty's cultural and historical achievements.

The more cards you have in play, the higher the tax you must collect from your populace. Tax is discarded directly from your hand, and eventually, you will not be able to maintain your growing empire. Collapse is inevitable! Players develop their provinces, fight for position in Provinces and collapse until one of the end-game conditions is met. Then everybody counts up their Victory Points. The person with the most Victory Points clearly has the Mandate of Heaven!

In the not-too-distant future, robots have spread all around the world. In every home, factory, art and sport, robots are replacing people, and to take advantage of their presence, the most exciting race in the world has been created in which robots are controlled by their owner's mind.

In RoboRace, players control their robots and their speed with different actions, but they must be careful since many other robots are racing, too, and they all have the same goal. On your turn, you play one card from your hand, trying to cover the most robots on the table. If you succeed, you earn points. You can increase your points by using your own action tokens or tokens that you got from the arena. The player who plays the best combinations and has the most points at the end of the race wins.

item.description: Mechana Rising is set in a sci-fi comic book universe in which factions fight for control of the world using giant mechs.

name.value: Million Dollars But... The Game: Expansion Pack 1

item.description:
A 100-card playable version of Million Dollars, But… The Game (MDB), a game that puts your morals and imagination to the test, posing the question, "What would you do for a million dollars?" Players create scenarios by combining a Trigger and a Rule card to showcase what they would or wouldn’t do for a big hunk of cash. (For example, A Million Dollars, But… Every time you see a store having a sale, you poop your pants a little bit.) The cards in the deck are exclusive to the expansion and features fill-in-the-blank cards.

The best part of the game occurs when everyone debates the scenarios that have been presented to the judge. “Does it include online store sales or just in-person sales?” “How much poop are we talking: a rabbit pellet or an uncomfortable amount?”

link.value: Million Dollars But... The Game: Community Pack #1

item.description: Print-n-play solitaire game of German WWII submarine warfare. Components include an 8 1/2" x 11" cardboard map; 7 dice; and 14 cubes. As U-Boat commander your mission is to sink as much Allied shipping as possible within a fast 20-turn time frame without yourself getting sunk. You have a limited supply of oxygen and torpedoes and an operational area of four depth level within which to maneuver and evade aerial attack and depth charges. Each patrol lasts no more than 5 minutes in this fun-filled yet intensive drama that unfolds above and below the dark seas of the Atlantic.

name.value: Dr. Livingstin's Sports Dice: Baseball Edition

item.description:
Sports Dice: Baseball — first released as Dr. Livingstin's Sports Dice: Baseball Edition — features all the baseball action of a real game, including triple plays, grand slams, steals and more.

Push your luck if you're feeling lucky in this fast-paced, easy-to-play game. Each team gets six dice and simultaneously rolls every play. One quick reference card is all you need to determine the outcome of your play (with no complicated instructions or charts).

name.value: Dr. Livingstin's Sports Dice: Football Edition

item.description:
Should you go for it on fourth down? Will your opponent sack you or cause a turnover?

Push your luck if you're feeling lucky in Dr. Livingstin's Sports Dice: Football Edition, a fast-paced, easy-to-play game. Each team gets six dice and simultaneously rolls every play. One quick reference card is all you need to determine the outcome of your play (with no complicated charts or instructions). Use the three advanced cards for even more football action, such as onside kicks and two-point conversions.

Island's Bounty is a treasure hunting board game set on an island. Players take turns rolling their dice, and exploring the grid of hex tiles on the board. Tile locations are marked in a notepad for future reference. Object tiles can be used to to help find treasure. For example, the Map allows a player to look at two face down tiles. Also, traps can be used on opponents. For instance, the Pit causes a player to lose a turn.

When a player has deduced the locations of at least two treasure tiles, the player may then begin placing their dice on the game board. The dice do not tell the exact locations of the Treasure tiles, rather, they tell the distance. The first person to place all three of their dice on the board wins the game.

Luck & Logic (ãƒ©ã‚¯ã‚¨ãƒ³ãƒ­ã‚¸ãƒƒã‚¯ Raku en Rojikku) or Lucklogi (ãƒ©ã‚¯ãƒ­ã‚¸ Rakuroji) is the newest trading card game by Bushiroad. It was first released in Japanese on January 28th, 2016 and in English on June 24th, 2016.

Luck & Logic is a two-player card game. Players are able to call allies, known as members, to the battlefield. By using the power of trance to combine regular humans called Logicalists and creatures from alternate worlds called Foreigners, players are able to call on Tranceunions to defeat their opponents and their differing logic!

Players build two decks to play with, utilizing cards from the trial/starter decks and booster packs: a 50 battle deck and a 10 card Gate deck. At the beginning of each game, players shuffle the Gate deck and place 6 randomly face down. Players then take turns utilizing the characters and tactics of their main deck to defend the 6 gates. First player to have 6 destroyed gates loses.

name.value: Der Besucher: Part 1 – The House with the red dog

item.description:
From the publisher:

In this labyrinth game, players assume the role of one of three mysterious young girl being chased by a dark stranger.

Players move besides their own character and the Red Dog, her protector, and the visitors, their enemy. Here a determined run mechanism and a malignant dice cause nerve-racking situations. But in order to escape yet, the girls need your help and all your skill.

From the publisher (translated):
In this Pachisi-style game, players roll the dice and move their pawns in a circle. The track goes around the roofs of an old city quarter. For the four main characters of the game, this is both home and hunting ground.

The town cats hunt mice, lose them again and steal them from each other. With the luck of the dice, things move around as quickly as you can call "You 've got the mouse!" can call. In this way, the game is also fun for the youngest players.

From the publisher (German):
In dieser Variante des indischen Pachisi, Vorlage für Mensch-ärgere-dich-nicht, wird in alter Tradition gewürfelt und mit den Spielfiguren im Kreis gezogen. Der Weg führt hoch über die Dächer eines alten Häuserviertels, das für die vier Hauptpersonen des Spiels Heimat und Jagdrevier in einem ist.

Die Stadtkatzen jagen Mäuse, verlieren sie wieder und schnappen sie sich gegenseitig weg. Mit dem Würfelglück geht es dabei schneller auf und ab, als man "Hab die Maus!" rufen kann. So macht die Jagd auch den Jüngsten Spaß.

From the publisher (translated):
Here, everything revolves around gold, sea battles and ships that can be sunk. The four most notorious pirates of the seas want to get the gold that is on board the galleons.

Players move around the sea chart, which is populated gold-laden galleons and the fearsome Kraken in addition to their pirates. Next to luck with the dice, a clever tactic and a nose for the right opportunity will decide who will be the next Pirate King of Kraken Island.

From the publisher (German):
Hier dreht sich alles um Gold, Seeschlachten und Schiffe, die es zu versenken gilt. Die vier berüchtigtsten Piraten der Meere wollen an das Gold an Bord der Galeonen kommen.

Die Spieler ziehen über die Seekarte, die neben ihren Piraten auch von goldbeladenen Galeonen und dem furchterregenden Kraken bevölkert wird. Neben dem Würfelglück entscheidet auch eine geschickte Taktik und eine Nase für die richtige Gelegenheit darüber, wer der nächste Piratenkönig der Krakeninsel wird.

Microworld is a challenging game for two players in which one player is a virus and the other controls antibodies. On your turn, you place a tile next to the tile your opponent has placed on the previous turn. Special tokens on the board can be collected and used any time as a special action. You score points for your own tiles in the neighborhood, and at the end of the game you score for a majority in each area of the microworld!

The game has eight modular rules that change the gameplay, and these rules can be combined in any way desired.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
In Clockwork Empire, players take the role of robots brought back to life many years after the demise of humans, with only the goal of increasing their numbers.

Players use dice to move and gain influence over the different spaces on the circular track, in order to gain resources, draw worker cards, build workers, take control of high-value Deus cards, and gain VP. The game ends when one player reaches 50 VP, and after a final accounting of VP for workers and Deus cards, the player with the most VP wins.

Honeybee Match! is an "Old Maid" style card game, with a couple of twists: the cards in your hand must be ordered lowest to highest (except the queen, which can be placed anywhere), certain pairs of cards have an effect when discarded, and the winner is the player that at any point has only the queen bee card in their hand.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
IronheadE is a two player card game based around structured play, strategy and timing. Using the cards at their disposal, players build a deck in any way they choose consisting of exactly twenty unique cards. Having built their twenty card decks, players shuffle their cards and draw the top ten cards and now, using those cards, the goal is to have the most points when both players have chosen to not play any further cards.

When you play a card it must be in the correct placement on your grid and all cards after your first must be touching the edge of a card in play, diagonals don't count.

Playing a card scores you the points written on it, both in the top left and anything you would gain through the ability text. Players keep track of this either on paper or with dice, or whatever you have available.

Players have two options on their turn, play and resolve one card from their hand or pass, but if you pass you can no longer play cards for the rest of the round. When the round ends the player with the higher points is the winner.

This is then repeated until one player wins twice.

The Dragon Games is a collection of four events all using the specially designed Dragon cards. Each card describes a unique dragon, with a name, colour, gender, age, strength, height, breath-type, behaviour and number of horns. There are also 12 Attribute cards, used in two of the games, 36 cardboard connectors, used in one game, and 12 gold medals, for scoring. The four games each take about 10 minutes, and use different skills.
The first event, formations, has players racing to put their dragons in piles or in order, depending on the attribute shown on the randomly produced Attribute card. 
Matches is the second event. Players look for things in common between two randomly chosen dragon cards, and use that to take an attribute card from the pool or another player, in order to get the required number of attribute cards.
The third event, Connections, incorporates connectors with the Dragon cards for a strategic domino type game, which uses comparisons to link or lock out other dragons.
The final event, Battle, is the simplest, as players take turns to decide which attribute wins a battle between randomly selected cards.
Cards are placed on the table, so there is no need to hold a hand of cards.
The events are easy to play and help practice mathematics skills.

Los pequeños exploradores avanzan por la jungla sorteando toda clase de obstáculos, en busca del cofre de oro de la la tarántula. Consigue ser el primero en alcanzar el centro del tablero con dos de tus exploradores pero... ¡ten cuidado con la tarántula, ya que podría enviarte de vuelta a casa!
__

Little explorers through the jungle dodging all sorts of obstacles, in the search of the golden casket of the tarantula. Get to be the first to reach the center of the board with two of your explorers but... beware of the tarantula, as it could send back to home!

After a series of natural disasters, the earth has been rocked by the reappearance of dinosaurs. The world governments are trying their best to quarantine these prehistoric beasts while they rampage through the streets of the new world.
 DinoProof is the fun and exciting 28mm miniature wargame for two or more players, featuring:

 Slayer Creation. Choose your Slayers abilities, skills and equipment
 Full rules for playing as a Slayer and a rampaging horde of dinosaurs
 Over a dozen profiles for the most dangerous and iconic dinosaurs ever to have walked the earth
 A full list of weapons and supplies to aid you on your adventures in the Dino Zones
 Full campaign rules so you can take your novice Slayer to the heights of a celebrity superstar
 8 exciting scenarios, from hunting dinosaurs, stealing rare eggs or tracking down a loose genetically designed super dinosaur
